snippet: Witnesses said radical Islamists in the northern Syrian city of Aleppo pulled 14-year-old Muhammad al-Qatta from his coffee kiosk on Sunday and later executed him.
abstract: Witnesses say radical Islamists in northern Syrian city of Aleppo pulled Muhammad al-Qatta from his coffee kiosk and later executed the teenager for refusing to give someone free cup of coffee; killing stokes feelings of public anger against hard-line Islamists who have seized on conflict as opportunity to impose their mores.

byline.original: By KAREEM FAHIM and HANIA MOURTADA
byline.contributor: Karam Shoumali contributed reporting from Antakya, Turkey, and an employee of The New York Times from Aleppo, Syria.

lead_paragraph: Witnesses said radical Islamists in the northern Syrian city of Aleppo pulled 14-year-old Muhammad al-Qatta from his coffee kiosk on Sunday and later executed him.

headline.seo: Teenager’s Death Reveals Growing Anger in Syria
headline.main: Syrian Teenager’s Public Death Reveals Growing Anger as Civil War Continues
headline.print_headline: Syrian Teenager’s Public Death Reveals Growing Anger as Civil War Continues
